description:
Schnipp & Weg, first released as Kosakenschubsen, is a flicking game for two players that's played on a game board shaped like an hourglass.

Each player starts on one end of the board with nine pieces of their own color. On a turn, you flick one of your pieces at one or more of the opponent's pieces, and if you manage to knock at least one opposing piece from the board while not flying off yourself, you take another turn; otherwise, the opponent takes their turn.

If you manage to remove all of the opposing pieces, you start the game again, but with you now having eight pieces instead of nine and with those pieces being one level closer to the center of the game board. Each round that you win, you start with one fewer piece and one level closer to the center. If you win a round after starting on the fifth row with only five pieces, then you win the game.

Portable lunchbox game. The Marvel Heroes are always equipped and ready to go and now you can follow suit. Have great time wherever your adventures take you. Heroes unite. Players 2-4.

Product Features
The Marvel Heroes are always equipped and ready to go and now you can follow suit
Have great time wherever your adventures take you
Heroes unite
For Ages 4+
Players 2-4

Players roll dice on their turns in order to match the superhero icons on the dice to the villains currently at large on the table. To capture a villain such as the Lizard requires one Spiderman icon. To capture Galactus requires one each of Captain America, Hulk and Spiderman. Players may reroll "misses" but once an "X" is rolled, that die cannot be rerolled so there is a slight press-your-luck element.

There are some wild cards that give players an icon of their choice. Some other special cards give players extra rerolls or force a player to give up one of their previously captured villains.

The winner is the player who has captured the most villains when the deck runs out.

Basically the game is very similar to the much better known game Pachisi. Each player is trying to move his pigs from his starting position around a race track and get them to the brick yard, which is "home" for the game.

There are some differences to the regular Pachisi game. There are only four safe spaces marked on the board. Also there are special spaces which tell a player to advance or to go back a certain number of spaces. Also there are only three pigs, not four.

Promotional game for a house improvements company.

The board looks interesting, with a track around the edge of a house which has a wall taken away so that you can see workmen in every room.

The game itself is not so interesting, being a close relative of games like Ludo, Pachisi and Mensch. To spice it up, if you land on a brown square you get to draw a card and must follow the instructions.

The first player to get all four of their men home is the winner.

A tactical level wargame based on the Japanese robotech animation "Panzer World Galient".
Two editions of the game were published, in Dual Magazine #11 and 12. Each edition uses the same basic rules, but with different map and units.

Players control one or more Panzer Soldiers (the mecha name in this universe).
Each turn, players secretly fill out the log for their action pattern and movement plan. Then, they simultaneously resolve movement and combat. The combat includes fire and close combat.

This game does not contain any scenarios. In the basic game, each player use one Panzer Soldier and battles to destroy the opponent. A skilled player can handle more units for large-scale battles.

You and your friends are managers of a Formula Fun racing team.

The winner is the player who obtains the highest number of points over the various championship races in which he participates.

To take part in a race, one must have first employed drivers and signed contracts for the supply of an engine and chassis and manage the finances from the sponsorship cards.

The finishing order of the cars is determined by adding the value of the chassis, engine and driver cards of each car taking into account any effect shown on the Circuit card.

Your progress in the championship will be subject to various positive and negative Special cards for you and your rivals who will do all possible to put a spoke in your wheels.

Racing Manager is an evolved version of Racing Formule Fun which was published in French in 2010. The principal differences concern tha packaging which is bigger and which contains banknotes and tokens (the French version didn't) and there are no more texts on the cards. So some cards have been simplified.

Taken from Kickstarter page

The dead have risen from their graves and their only desire is to devour brains of the living.  Sure, it's fun to tell your friends you killed a zombie.  But it's even better to add "Oh, you may have heard of him."  That's why these zombies are famous.  Will they keep coming back? Most definitely. Will humanity survive? Not even close. But if you can take out a few of the better know walking dead along the way, then you could win.

Game Play:

Players use cards to place player tokens on different spaces.  Placing them on the main board allows players to search for and use weapons to kill and drive back zombies.  The trap area allows your tokens to electrocute or blow up zombies that wander across the board.  Intel spaces allow players to draw additional cards.  The more cards that are drawn, the faster the zombies come.

Zombies are constantly springing up and slowly moving toward the brains on the main board.  When they reach them, players lose player tokens.  Players may regain player tokens by using cards to recruit new allies from the "Eaten" space.

Zombies will come in waves.  Sometimes they give you time to set up your strategy, and sometimes they emerge so quickly and in such large numbers that you must take action immediately.

Famous Zombies is a victory point based game that can be learned quickly and has enough choices to make strategy the most important factor in winning.

From the companies website: www.panzerbattles.com

Panzer Battles (ages 10+) is a card game based on World War II armor combat in a fast and fun system for 2-8 players. All players start the game with five cards form the tank deck (their active tank units) and five cards from the action deck. If you ever happen to run out of tanks, it is game over.

Winning the Game

The goal of the game is to destroy all enemy tanks and artillery before they destroy you! the players decide what the total score will be for victory (typically 150 points). This may result in playing multiple rounds until someone achieves the agreed points to win the game.

The Earth is a dead husk. Having mined all of its resources, facing a population many times that which could be possibly sustained and slowly mutating it into a massive, cloying, choking city, we had no choice but to set our greedy eyes on the planets around us and conquer new lands.

After the Information War of the 21st century, the Corporations dissolved national borders and began a new war of their own: the Resource War. Like their European ancestors, who conquered and fought over new land, the corporations started to clash for control of the stars around Earth, as if they had claims to them from the moment of their conception.

Thus began the new arms race, but this time the lessons learned from past wars would be embraced and used to leverage as much advantage as possible. Research into more advanced abilities to control not only the battles, but the hearts and minds of the people who fight them would become key to victory.

Steel Stars is a game of intergalactic warfare amongst rival corporations in Earth's dark future with a near endless number of system configurations and multiple paths to victory – through the council, through research of technologies and advanced abilities, via the creation of popular utopian worlds, or by the might of your powerful fleets.

Each player steps into the powerful and all encompassing shoes of the head of one of the five corporations fighting for the control of the universe. You will need to use cunning, guile, diplomacy, deception, and tactical thinking to make the decisions that will hopefully bring victory, control, renown, and respect to your corporation.

In each round of the game, players select four actions to perform. Players in turn perform one of these. Whenever an action is performed, all other players may also perform that action. The available actions are: Fleet (move ships), Research (develop tech), Council (Create votes on new rules), Planetary (develop your civilization), Energy (generate resources) and Logistics (build new ships). Players score points for colonising worlds, developing tech, building colonies, passing votes and developing their civilisation. The game ends when one player has accumulated 15 points, but that player does not necesarily win, as there are bonus points scored for being the best player in each of several categories.

"Snakes, lizards & Co."

The nature quiz for children with 32 color printed cards held together by a hinge.

Whether the answer is correct player scores a point.
At the end of the game the player with the most points wins.

"Life in the Sea"

The nature quiz for children with 32 color printed cards held together by a hinge.

Whether the answer is correct player scores a point.
At the end of the game the player with the most points wins.

"Animals of the World"

63 cards age-appropriate questions and answers are represented.
Answer correctly and win the card.
Player with the most points if the deck is exhausted is the winner.

"Learning English"

63 cards age-appropriate questions and answers are represented.
Answer correctly and win the card.
Player with the most points if the deck is exhausted is the winner.

A quizgame for the youngest players. The cards are held by a screw and can be ideally taken on travels, 
More than 1,100 questions and answers - themes: nature, animals, seasons, shapes, colors, maps - ideal for travel -
the answers are always on the next page. The quiz can be played alone or by several players.

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The ultimate knowledge-check! Test your skills on the subject of more brain training! Confusing and challenging puzzles to think and thinking around the corner. 50 exercises and solutions

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with confusing and challenging puzzles to think and thinking around the corner. The backside of each card contains the answers.

Solve the puzzle first and get the card as a point. Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

A brand new evolution of Pox: Save the People, ZOMBIEPOX challenges 1-4 players to stop an approaching zombie apocalypse by vaccinating humans against the ZOMBIEPOX. Cure those in the most dire situations and protect the vulnerable who cannot be immunized. (No one wants zombie babies!) Win the game if the deadly ZOMBIEPOX can no longer spread. Lose if too many people become full-blown zombies.

Not only is the game fun, but through play and the zombie themed narrative, players gain an understanding of group immunity, the need to vaccinate, and systems thinking. Casual and hardcore gamers from 12-65 and have enjoyed ZOMBIEPOX.

Players alternate drawing cards. Each card specifies how the ZOMBIEPOX spreads, and then which resources the player has to combat the outbreak. It's important to protect the vulnerable people on the board, because if they become infected, they immediately succumb to zombification.

"Monstrum" (Monster) is a quite easy fantasy quest type game. Game objectives which players have to achieve to win are: 1) to reach place called "Kopalnia Zezere" (Zezere Mine) after: 2) killing at least one Monster, 3) gaining 30 points of strenght.

During the game players have to fight with hostile creatures. They can sometimes find special objects and gain spells which can be used in further fights or help in achieving game goal.

There is almost no interaction between players - which can be recognized as a big minus in gameplay.

The origins of the game are dated in 1985 when Jacek Ciesielski published its rules, cards and board in magazine "Razem" (Together). Rules and board for this earlier version were different. Graphics on game cards were simpler, but almost every player who had opportunity to play 1985 and 1990 versions claims that older version is better looking. Changes in 1990 probably gone too far ;)

Graphic design came from Polish comics artist - Witold ParzydÅ‚o.

NinjitZoo is an action packed card game in which you assist a bunch of martial art animals - the Ninjanimals - escape their caged confines within an obstacle rigged zoo.

Three characters are randomly dealt out to each player at the start of the game. The first person to assist all their ninjanimals in escaping - wins! This is accomplished by using the escape routes, which are drawn from the deck each turn. However, the deck also contains obstacles that can block your ninjanimal from freedom.

But you'll have lots of help along the way. Don the Mysterious Mo to slip past a patrol of guards, or grab a Thickslick Rope to rendezvous on the roof. That Hovering Heli giving you trouble? Throw down a Smoke Bomb and Back Flip out of there!

And watch out for the robots, time portals, piranha infested moats, and all the lasers.

Upon the call of Pharaoh Snofru, up to four princes receive the order to build a glorious avenue in front of the red pyramid and to fill the grave chamber with precious and shining objects.

Using their influence cards in Dahschur: Die Rote Pyramide, the player princes will buy gems for the construction of the avenue and try to position them for the filling of the grave chamber. They'll also use presents from the neighboring cities. The possibilities for each player, however, very much depends on the influence used by the other princess.

Receiving the most goodwill from the Pharaoh will require perfect utilization of the influence cards and the gathering of valuables for the grave chamber.


For the fulfilment of the Red Pyramid, Pharaoh Snofru orders the construction of an avenue and the filling of the grave chambers. In this complex strategy game, the players - acting as princes - use their limited influence to become the grand vizier. By clever usage of action cards and commodities, the players buy gems on the market, use them in the construction of the avenue, achieve beneficial positions for the filling of the grave chambers and use the tributes of the neighbouring settlements – all possibilities to score directly or at the end of the game. However, these tasks, asked by the pharaoh, cannot be solved alone! The dilemma: The player’s action potential depends on the cards chosen by the other players, which are pursuing their own goals...

To score at the end of the game, the players not only have to place their offerings in the procession, but will have to collect gold and silver as well in order to fill the grave chambers – preferably by hindering the other players from doing so. The player having collected the most recognition points will receive the title of the grand vizier in the end.

Special feature of the game: The game box is designed as a pyramid, revealing the burial chamber when opened.

Game description from the publisher:

In Der Hobbit: Eine unerwartete Reise - Das Spiel zum Film, each player will set off with his two dwarfs on a shared, yet perilous journey with the hobbit Bilbo Baggins. Along the way, they will encounter trolls, dangerous orcs, voracious wights, vicious spiders, and – if they're lucky – the wizard Gandalf, who will lend his support.

In the Misty Mountains, Bilbo will find the One Ring, with which he must defy many hidden dangers. Should the players make it through Mirkwood, they all win together.

What's in the box:


     1 rulebook
     1 game board
     1 6-sided die
     1 ring
     8 dwarf pawns (2 in each of the four player colors)
     1 Bilbo pawn (violet)
     1 Gandalf pawn (grey)
     1 Orc Stone token
     118 playing cards:
         20 movement cards (5 in each of the four player colors)
         10 Trollshaws adventure cards
         16 Misty Mountains adventure cards
         44 Shire playing cards
         16 Rivendell playing cards
         12 Carrock playing cards

Game description from the publisher:

In Gregs Tagebuch: Von Idioten umzingelt!, you're new at school and (as might be expected) at the very bottom of the class in terms of popularity – but that situation can change through your cool actions. Just don't risk too much for popularity as whoever touches the stinky cheese gets cursed by the cheese and will see his prestige plunge!

In the game, each player represents a character from the first volume of the popular book series, and everyone wants their character to rise to the top. To do this, you need to select one or more cards from a pile. Most cards have positive values and help you climb the ladder of success, but negative cards exist as well. Worst of all is the stinky cheese that adheres to your fingers and drops your popularity. Your only hope is to pass the curse on to another player, who will then stink even worse than you...

Educational range of games. This one deals with the Human Body. It is a very simple card game. You get asked a question. If you get it right, you gain a point. If you get it wrong, you lose a point. When the questions run out, or an agreed time-limit has been reached, the player with the most points wins.

From the publisher's website:

CONQUEST, WAR AND FAMINE OH MY!

And don’t forget Death. Commonly referred to as the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse they rode through the land signaling the end of the world. What caused the end of mankind, the end game? Who knows? Who cares? The real question is…

WHAT HAPPENS AFTER THE HORSEMEN?
After the Horsemen takes place after mankind has broken down. How’d it happen? Who really cares? As one of the few people still alive it’s your goal to survive and thrive in this new world. While some view it as the end of the world a few think of it as a new beginning. Kind of like the glass being half empty or half full, it’s all how you look at it.

After the Horsemen includes:

     Three character classes for your character, Sheep, Pack Wolves or Lone Wolves, each with their own specific way to behave. After the Apocalypse things are so much simpler.
     Over forty Signatures and Skills that allows you to customize and differentiate your main character, your Star, you!
     A variety of items ranging from food to “luxury items, those things that make life worth living in these troubled times. Those things you have to collect to survive.
     Various weapons to insure that you get those items.
     A number of pre-generated Encounters and the how to info for designing your own.
     A light book keeping campaign system to link your adventures.


After the Horsemen can be played solo or cooperatively, with all players on the same side, against the game mechanics. It can also be played head to head against your friends. After the Horsemen is compatible with All Things Zombie – Better Dead Than Zed and other Two Hour Wargames products.


Your SUV has a full of tank of gas and you’ve got food for a week or two. Weapons? You cleaned them, again, last night before saying your good-byes. You’re not sure which way to go but you know that it’s time to go. You start the engine and adjust your sunglasses, you’re off.

AFTER THE HORSEMEN THE GAME OF THE APOCALYPSE

(1) After the Horsemen is strictly a human centric PA game. No zombies, no aliens, no mutants, etc., just humans versus humans. If you’re looking for that sort of thing try All Things Zombies and 5150: New Beginnings, both are fully compatible with After the Horsemen.

The newly discovered "Expanse" contains a wide variety of astronomical phenomenon in improbably close proximity.  The race is now on to unravel the mysteries of this new microcosm, and prestigious research institutions with deep pockets are clamoring to be the first to know.   New, highly experimental ships are commissioned that can quickly move between systems using powerful, volatile drives and reality altering engines. Can you pilot one to victory?

Players compete to be the first to explore eight of the nine phenomenon using cards drawn from a common deck.  Different cards can provide fuel or special abilities, be played as anomalies, or be used to explore the different locations in The Expanse.

A simple board game for small children, based on the award winning picture book of the same name. Players choose a character piece - one of the family members from the book, or even the family dog - and then spin and move around the board. There are two piles of cards on the board - the Uh-uh! cards and the What's that? cards. If a player lands on an Uh-uh! space on the board he/she turns over the top card in that pile. A green card allows him/her to spin again and move past the obstacle; a red card means he has to wait until his next turn before moving.

Two thirds of the way around the board a player will reach the rainbow space just before the cave. Tentatively he turns over the top card in that pile. If the card shows an empty cave he yells 'Quick' and speeds past the cave to the next space. But if there is a bear in the cave ... Yikes! wait another turn and hope to get past next time.

This really is a simple game but small children who know and love this wonderful picture book are likely to love the re-enactment of the story in this way.

In the board game players bearer squads consist of 20 soldiers and placement of the order is completely random. In total six different types of soldiers, among whom is an officer-bearer, who could command the whole ranks. The game used a system of ranks and strength of a warrior, depending on the state of health.

  Before the beginning party players are laid out face down tiles of soldiers under the original arrangement. After that, all tiles are revealed and the game begins.
For his turn, a player must move a warrior and a tile to tile a single attack of the enemy. Bearer can move itself, and can also move the entire vertical or horizontal column of soldiers who are with him.

The winner is the player who destroyed the first of three standard-bearers of the enemy.

Chit Chat Girls' Night Out is a 'Girls only' game, revolving around 252 questions, "written by women for women", such as:


     What would you like to change about your partner?
     When cooking, do you follow the recipe, or do you improvise?
     Which friend from the past would you like to see again?
     Do you prefer large passion, or quiet love?


The questions are divided into different categories. Each round, one player (the gamemaster) rolls a die which determines the category. She draws a card from that category, which lists three questions, from which she aks one. Now, the other players have to answer the question. After all players have answer, the gamemaster gives one 'gemstone' from the stock to the player whose answer she liked best, for whatever reason.

The game ends when all gemstones have been handed out; the player who has collected the most gemstones wins the game.

Objective: Using the detailed street map of Nürnberg each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

Findus has birthday three times per year. And every time Petterson bakes him a pancake cake. But this time he is still lacking 5 eggs - who can get hold of them first?

Players choose a basket of eggs on the board and then search the eggs with matching color. If the underside of an egg shows the wrong color, it is returned back to the board without showing the color to the other players. The first player to have found his five eggs is the winner.

In the second variant a die is rolled, then an egg matching the rolled color is sought, and if both match, the egg is placed in the player's basket. If the die shows Petterson, one can put any egg from the board in his basket. If it shows Findus, one egg has to be returned from the basket to the board. The first player to fill his basket is the winner.

Prepare for awkwardness! Each round  in Awkward Moment puts 3-8 players in terrifically awkward social situations. Take turns being the Decider. Draw a moment Card to a reveal hysterical, embarrassing, or stressful situation. Use the Decider Card to determine the basis for a winning Reaction. Impress the Decider by submitting the best response from your hand!

Mix Fix is a reaction game where you are trying to get rid of all your cards first.
In the beginning every player get six cards showing six symbols. There are 4 different symbols in this game (fish, ship, sheep, frog). In each round 4 dice are rolled. Each dice has one symbol on four sides plus two blank sides. The players must then quickly find a card which shows all rolled symbols. If a matching card is found the player has to put it quickly in the middle of the table and has to name all symbols. If all was correct the player gets rid of this card. If he has made a mistake (wrong card or misspelling) he has to take it back and gets a new card as penalty.

This volume in Volko Ruhnke's COIN Series takes 1 to 4 players into the Afghan conflict of today’s headlines, this time in a unique collaboration between two top designers of boardgames on modern irregular warfare.  A Distant Plain teams Volko Ruhnke, the award-winning designer of Labyrinth: The War on Terror, with Brian Train, a designer with 20 years' experience creating influential simulations such as Algeria, Somalia Interventions, Shining Path: The Struggle for Peru, and many others.

A Distant Plain features the same accessible game system as GMT's recent Andean Abyss and upcoming Cuba Libre but with new factions, capabilities, events, and objectives.  For the first time in the Series, two counterinsurgent (COIN) factions must reconcile competing visions for Afghanistan in order to coordinate a campaign against a dangerous twin insurgency.

A Distant Plain adapts familiar Andean Abyss mechanics to the conditions of Afghanistan without adding rules complexity.  A snap for Series: COIN (GMT) players to learn, A Distant Plain will transport them to a different place and time.  New features include:


     Coalition-Government joint operations.
     Volatile Pakistani posture toward the conflict.
     Evolution of both COIN and insurgent tactics and technology.
     Government graft and desertion.
     Coalition casualties.
     Returning Afghan refugees.
     Pashtun ethnic terrain.
     Multiple scenarios.
     A deck of 72 fresh events.


... and more.

As with each COIN Series volume, players of A Distant Plain will face difficult strategic decisions with each card.  The innovative game system smoothly integrates political, cultural, and economic affairs with military and other violent and non-violent operations and capabilities.  Flow charts are at hand to run the three Afghan factions, so that any number of players—from solitaire to 4—can experience the internecine brawl that is today's Afghanistan.

Meltdown Express is a nuclear plant escape game for two players. It uses a die in a non-luck way.

In turns, each player can move one of his three workers to get one of the three hatchways on the other side of the modular board. Each hatchway has different victory points.

You have to run hard and strategic to achieve the objective of not dying and score most points.

This game was made for the II "Imprimir y Jugar" contest of the spanish blog "Jugando en Pareja" and got de second position.

German game for young children to enhance their early English language skills.

Six player boards are included and 36 tiles, each representing a common English word and the associated image.

Two games are described. The first is Englische Bildpaare suchen, a version of Pairs or Memory. You don't use the boards. Instead, turn all the tiles face down and lay them out on the table. Children must find the pairs, which are not two of the exact same image but instead, two tiles that 'go together'. Examples: Cow and Milk, Jacket and Trousers, and so on. If you 'match' a pair, you take the two tiles. When all the tiles are matched, the player with the most tiless, wins.

The second game uses the player boards and is played like Picture Bingo or Lotto. The first player to complete a line of three images is the winner.

The 25 tiles are laid out face-down. In a turn, a player rolls both the dice. Now he must choose one of the tiles which contains both colours that were rolled. Each card is a combination of two colours, the background color and the object colour.

If a player is correct, he takes the card. If not, he must replace it face down in the same position it was when he chose it.

When all the cards are taken, the player with the most tiles wins.

A variant for older children is included. In this game, the various tiles have a points value and the winner is the player with the most points, not neccessarily the player who has the most tiles.

A filler type old-style card game where you draw 1, play 1 to claim steer cards. Whoever has the most steer cards when the deck (45 cards) is depleted and all cards are played out (from 3 card hands) wins. You can claim a steer card directly by playing a Bar X card, or claim someone's steer card / Bar X stack by playing a Rustler, or claim someone's steer card / Bar X / Rustler stack by playing a Deputy.

The rules say it's best played with 2, 3, or 4 players, but 5 or 6 may play if desired.

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with confusing and challenging puzzles to think and thinking around the corner. The backside of each card contains the answers.

Solve the puzzle first and get the card. Player with the most cards at the end of the game wins the game.

High performance sport for your brain: Clever puzzles, lateral thinking, concentration exercises, puzzles, logical thinking.

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

Test your knowledge on the subject of Impressionism! Everything to know about the most famous painters of this period and your world-famous works.

Answer the question correctly first and get the card.
Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

There are 20 illustrated cards with body parts of a pirates and 20 text cards. Now we have to roll the dice, take a word card, properly read and look closely: Should it be the pirate with a mustache or beard with? With sabers or with the saw? With this fun card game to practice first-graders to read and understand exactly what has been read correctly.
Be the quickest the recognize the illustrated card.

Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Mercenaries, a stand-alone game that also functions as an expansion for any Resident Evil DBG title, brings the Mercenaries theme to life, giving your characters brand new Skill cards to be used in any style of play. Draft Skill cards at the beginning of a game to give your Character a completely different play style.

Your character will learn from those failures and successes as you continue to play, using that experience to activate the Skills they have to give them an edge in battle.

Mercenaries also introduces three different Mansions with three different challenges. Will you face the unruly Ganados horde, the creepy Illuminados, or the onslaught of Majini? Each Mansion attacks the player in a different way, leaving a multitude of combinations for ultimate replay value!

Content:
275 cards 
30 card dividers

Integrates with:

    Resident Evil Deck Building Game
    Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Alliance


Expanded by:

    Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Outbreak
    Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Nightmare

The game has 13 letter dice that players roll up to three times, trying to form a crossword with them before a sand timer runs out. When a player is done or time runs out, they score the value of the words minus the value of unused dice. First one to reach an agreed score (usually 200 points) wins the game.

A classic since the late '70s - early '80s, Rapigrama remains one of the most popular boardgames in Argentina, sold in every toy store and supermarket.

The BATTLESHIP LIVE game is only available at toy and game retailers in Australia, France and Canada, and through select online retailers in the United States.

Go live! In this fun version of the classic BATTLESHIP game, the electronic talking tower calls the plays! With motion sensing, sound effects and even surprise game-changing events, the tower guides the game from start to finish while you plot your strategy and command your ships. Launch the spy plane to spot your enemy and use your ship’s special powers to sweep for mines, launch air attacks, fire missiles and more. With so many things to do, this “naval battle” is more thrilling than ever!

Players issue commands by placing the round command peg on the fire, move, spy plane or special power locations on the board.
Then you confirm the command by covering both confirm buttons.
The voice commamd tower will do the rest and guide the game from start to finish.

In 1887 the McLoughlin Brothers introduced a successful  series of educational card games under the name "Grandmama's XXX Game." The series included card games on Arithmetic, Bible Studies, Geography, Riddles. and Useful Knowledge.

One player was designated the "preceptor" and the other players were "scholars." The preceptor would ask questions and go around the players until someone got the question right. Most right answers wins.

"Grandmama's Arithmetical Game" card game had 119 question cards, an instruction sheet, and an answer booklet which were packaged in a paper covered cardboard box.

Benjamin Blümchen says "Shopping is fun".

Each player gets a board with 16 squares, all illustrated with things Benjamin needs at the supermarket. The item tiles are shuffled and placed in a face-down stack. A turn starts when the player reveals the top tile. If he thinks he needs it, he pays to the bank the cost (in Deutschmarks). If he doesn't want to buy it, the next player can, and at a saving of 50 Pfennigs (half a Deutschmark). If not wanted it is offered to all the other players, knocking off 50 Pfennigs each time. If it gets down to zero, that player will get it for free.

The object is to buy goods that will form four boxes in a row on your board, so four across, four down and four corner-to-corner are all acceptable choices. The first to do so, wins.

A few tiles are what you might call Event tiles. If one of these is drawn, it is read out and takes place if the drawer wants to make use of it. Example: You may take one item off the board of the player to your left.

In Movie Trailer, players take turns being the director and teasing one another with clues about a movie they have in mind.

In a round, the active player (a.k.a. the director) chooses a movie title and writes it down in secret. She then chooses one of the genre tiles to provide a first clue as to what the movie is. The player to her left is the spectator, and if no one guesses the movie, the spectator chooses one of three groups of clue tiles, from which the director chooses one and offers it to all as the next clue, with players being able to guess in clockwise order, starting with the spectator. Whoever first guesses the movie in question earns points, with more points being awarded the earlier that the player guesses correctly. The director tries to choose a movie title that can be guessed not too early and not too late for she scores the most points if the title is guessed after four clues. If no one has guessed the title after seven clues, no one scores and the spectator becomes the new director.

After all players have been director at least once — or an equal number of turns in a longer game — the player with the most points wins.

Objective: be the first reaching the target

- acting/moving by turn -
roll the die and use points to move your meeple and/or dig
 - one point per movement/digging;
digging means => put slides on the board or move/turn them;
players may start with a certain no. of obstacles (danger cards - max. 6) which are going to spoil movement.

Objective: be the first to reach the target (field 48)

- moving by turn -
roll the die, move your meeple & follow instructions of the field you land on..
Equipment: board, 6 (hard working) meeples, 2 dice

Checkers meets blackjack.

The goal is to get a game piece to the other side of the board, and score as close to 21 as possible without busting.  Pieces can only with forward, with the exception of the Ace, which can also move backwards.  If you have the opportunity to jump a piece, you are required to jump it.

Objective:
get most question cards finding correct answers
In his turn draw a card and give the correct answer;
if you are right keep card as bonus point.

64 question and answer cards, informative and curious about geography, politics, celebrities, to culinary, recreational activities and history of Austria.
